author: NotWearingPants
body:
## Steps to reproduce

Copy the following text and paste it in powershell:
```powershell
echo hello
#	comment
echo world
```

## Expected behavior

Should print `hello` and `world`.

## Actual behavior

Prints `hello`, `hellocomment`, and `world`

## Notes

What happens is that pasting the `#` character followed by a tab character triggers tab-completion and completes to the last command.
So the result is the previous command, `echo hello`, and then the comment text, `comment`, which results in `echo hellocomment`.

This is very unexpected. I had a function with a comment which had an indentation inside it, and the function broke when I pasted its definition in powershell.

## Environment data

```
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

Duplicate of PowerShell/PSReadLine#579

Workaround is to use <kbd>CTRL</kbd> + <kbd>v</kbd> instead of right click.

title: Pasting a tab character triggers tab-completion
